articles.headline: Infosys Built Its Global Machine With Indian Workers. Can It Adjust to Trump’s ‘Hire American’?
articles.snippet: Doing significantly more work in the United States, as the company is being pressured to do, would require an overhaul of its business model and corporate culture.
articles.abstract: Doing significantly more work in the United States, as the company is being pressured to do, would require an overhaul of its business model and corporate culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Infosys, a big Indian technology outsourcing company, opened a new office in Indianapolis this year, executives hailed it as a step along a new path.

articles.headline: U.S. Credit Card Giants Flout India’s New Law on Personal Data
articles.snippet: As India develops new rules governing the data of its residents, global firms are the first target. Companies say they need more time to comply.
articles.abstract: As India develops new rules governing the data of its residents, global firms are the first target. Companies say they need more time to comply.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — When the clock struck midnight in Delhi at the end of Monday, Visa, Mastercard and American Express were suddenly in violation of the law every time an Indian swiped a credit or debit card.

articles.headline: Sears Plan to Get Out of Bankruptcy Has a Familiar Ring
articles.snippet: The retailer says it will do more of what it has been doing in recent years: closing stores and borrowing more money from its controlling shareholder.
articles.abstract: The retailer says it will do more of what it has been doing in recent years: closing stores and borrowing more money from its controlling shareholder.
articles.lead_paragraph: In its bankruptcy filing on Monday, Sears argued that, given enough time and less debt, it would be able to reverse the decades-long decline of its retail business.

articles.headline: Paul G. Allen, Microsoft’s Co-Founder, Is Dead at 65
articles.snippet: Mr. Allen and Bill Gates started the company in 1975, helping to usher in the personal computing revolution. He died after a recurrence of cancer.
articles.abstract: Mr. Allen and Bill Gates started the company in 1975, helping to usher in the personal computing revolution. He died after a recurrence of cancer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Paul G. Allen, the co-founder of Microsoft who helped usher in the personal computing revolution and then channeled his enormous fortune into transforming Seattle into a cultural destination, died on Monday in Seattle. He was 65.

articles.headline: Utilities Cut Power to Prevent Wildfires. But Who Wins When the Lights Go Out?
articles.snippet: Citing safety concerns, power companies in California are shutting down electricity when and where the hazard is greatest. Consumer advocates see a strong-arm strategy to change liability law.
articles.abstract: Citing safety concerns, power companies in California are shutting down electricity when and where the hazard is greatest. Consumer advocates see a strong-arm strategy to change liability law.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — With devastating wildfires becoming more frequent in California, power companies have found themselves on the defensive. Their equipment has been singled out as a frequent culprit. Now, to reduce the hazard, they are pulling out a rarely used tool: the blackout.

articles.headline: When Business Executives Become Reluctant Statesmen
articles.snippet: Without a strong stance from Washington to give them cover, top executives have been on their own dealing with Saudi Arabia, a country that has shown itself capable of holding a grudge.
articles.abstract: Without a strong stance from Washington to give them cover, top executives have been on their own dealing with Saudi Arabia, a country that has shown itself capable of holding a grudge.
articles.lead_paragraph: How can we get out of this?

articles.headline: ‘You Are Still Black’: Charlottesville’s Racial Divide Hinders Students
articles.snippet: The New York Times and ProPublica examined the Charlottesville, Va., school system, which has one of the biggest racial gaps in the country.
articles.abstract: The New York Times and ProPublica examined the Charlottesville, Va., school system, which has one of the biggest racial gaps in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — This article was reported and written in a collaboration with ProPublica, the nonprofit investigative journalism organization.
articles.byline: By Erica L. Green and Annie Waldman

articles.headline: Is It Possible to Be an Anti-Abortion Democrat? One Woman Tried to Find Out
articles.snippet: In Missouri, where Democrats’ fortunes have been dwindling for years, party members are trying to figure out how to win back voters.
articles.abstract: In Missouri, where Democrats’ fortunes have been dwindling for years, party members are trying to figure out how to win back voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Joan Barry has been a member of the Missouri Democratic Party for 53 years. As a state legislator, she voted regularly for workers’ rights, health care and programs for the poor.

articles.headline: Trump Jumps to the Defense of Saudi Arabia in Khashoggi Case
articles.snippet: President Trump accused Saudi Arabia’s critics of presuming guilt, as Secretary of State Mike Pompeo met with Saudi leaders in Riyadh to help defuse a crisis.
articles.abstract: President Trump accused Saudi Arabia’s critics of presuming guilt, as Secretary of State Mike Pompeo met with Saudi leaders in Riyadh to help defuse a crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Trump administration pushed back on Tuesday against rising condemnation of Saudi Arabia and showed support for its crown prince, who has been linked to the disappearance and possible murder of a leading dissident journalist inside a Saudi consulate in Turkey.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard, Rick Gladstone and Mark Landler
